title: Are The Beatles albums being constantly remastered because they sound better, or is it to make the record company more money? - Quora

response.answer_text: I would say both are the case. Giles Martin, son of the Beatles’ renowned producer, George Martin, and one of the world’s top music engineers/producers in his own right, has endeavored in the last 15 years to bring the possibilities of modern sound engineering and new imagination to the Beatles’ catalogue. Yet, Giles also has been studiously adherent in that process to the creative integrity and original vision that went into the recordings the Beatles and his father made. That said, Beatles songs and their commercial brand remain an extremely lucrative source of income to the label and related businesses. So, why not keep generating revenue by remastering and re-selling new versions of the recordings? After all, Paul and Ringo’s grandkids need shoes.

Well, hmm. A bit peeved at your q. People (the millions in the recording business) need t make a living. Don’t you? Not to sound rude here to you or anyone, but - it probably is both. I enjoy the new remixes; I don’t have that good an ear to hear the subtle differences sometimes. But with the Beatles, all of their stuff is highly interesting, so let them remaster it! And more is in the vaults which we’d love to hear (and buy!) So it’s both, and nuthin’ wrong with that. No one is forced to buy it.

Dyu guys realize the Beatles catalog is worth 3 BILLION $$$ ???? Sure its about money..BUT A few million here& there is not going to make or break the label !!!! As sound tech is advanced , everything is remastered - just like film - it is inevitable & of course they want to keep improving the product & raise profits at same time!!!!

The Beatles were always recorded using the technology of the times. As new technology comes along, those recordings can be improved. Theoretically, with each new technology, the recordings become better. I like this guys work a whole lot: Dave Nevins — Beatles Redux  Enjoy!
Mostly to make more money for the record company. Unless you have top grade equipment, the sound will not be worth paying for the same music over and over.
When classic records get remastered multiple times you have to wonder the point is other than marketing and sales.
I was under the impression that only two ie Sgt Pepper and Abbey Road have been remastered more than once
